titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Office of Communications, Vice President, Office Files of Alex Wilde
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Office of Communications, Vice President, Office Files of Alex Wilde FA1892

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2025-04-01 04:19:59 UTC.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Office of Communications, Vice President, Office Files of Alex Wilde

physdesc.extent: 9 document boxes: 8 letter boxes and 1 half-letter box

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at the RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files, and officers' papers were transferred to and accessioned by the RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.
This material was transferred to the RAC in four accessions between 2021 and 2024 and was ingested by the RAC as Accessions 2021:091, 2021:111, 2023:048, and 2024:011.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is comprised of one series.
Original order was maintained as much as possible.
The collection arrangement is as follows:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains the office files Alexander, "Alex", Wilde created when he served as Vice President of the Ford Foundation's Office of Communications. The collection consists of one series of subject files.

While the collection primarily holds files from Wilde's position as Communications Vice President, there are also some materials Wilde created during his previous role as Foundation Representative for the Andean Region and Southern Cone when he was based in the Santiago, Chile Office. Some Communications related files originate from before Wilde became Vice President. They document a broader time frame of the Communications Office's strategy and activities.

Wilde's files provide insight into the Office of Communications' activities and challenges during the early 2000s. They concern the Foundation's communications strategy during a period of increased scrutiny of private foundations following the September 11 World Trade Center attack in 2001. They also document the Foundation's actions to keep pace with media trends of the time such as through the development of its website. Other records regard Communications Office responsibilities for Foundation publication preparation and dissemination, media coverage and relations, and advising Foundation executive staff on public statements.

Common material formats found within the collection include correspondence, memos, notes, drafts, reports, articles, news clippings, press releases, publications, speech transcripts, and meeting materials. There are a few pieces of Wilde's writings and a couple photographs.

did.unittitle: Subject files

physdesc.extent: 9 document boxes: 8 letter boxes and 1 half-letter box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the subject files Alexander, "Alex", Wilde created and maintained while he served as Vice President of the Ford Foundation's Office of Communications. It includes some files Wilde inherited from before he became Communications Vice President and a few files he created in his earlier position as Foundation Representative for the Andean Region and Southern Cone at the Santiago, Chile Office.

Wilde's Communications Office files document the Foundation's media response and strategy during a period of controversy for private foundations in the early 2000s. Events like the fallout from the United Nations World Conference on Racism in Durban, South Africa, public scrutiny of foundations and charities' giving practices after the September 11 World Trade Center attack in 2001, and the proposed House of Representative Bill 7 regarding private foundations' annual contributions to charities concerned the Communications Office's public relations work. Materials show that, at this same time, the Communications Office worked to keep the Foundation's public relations tools current with contemporary media trends through branding and the Foundation's public website. Other activities documented in the series include broader communications strategy development, Foundation publication preparation and dissemination, media coverage of Foundation activities, and support for Foundation executive staff on developing public statements. Wilde's files include his correspondence, notes, and a few of his writings.

There are files from Wilde's transition from Representative for the Andean Region and Southern Cone to the Communications Office. Some of these files pertain to his activities in the Santiago Office. Other materials from before Wilde's tenure as Communications Vice President give evidence of a longer history of communications strategy and public relations projects at the Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains a photograph. The photograph depicts a group at the International Roundtable of Journalism and Freedom of Expression in Santiago, Chile. Alex Wilde is in the photograph.
There is a caption on the back of the photograph. It identifies the individuals in the photograph.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains a photograph. The photograph is of Ford Foundation President Susan Berresford.
There is a caption on the back of the photograph. The photograph is dated March 1996, and the credit belongs to Ben Russell.
